evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative explanations do not sufficiently account for the observed coordination issues in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim dataset.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim data, such as timing and interaction patterns.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the historical pair engine preliminary phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution demonstrates resistance to common defeaters, maintaining its validity within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim scope, reflecting deviations from standard pushback protocols.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim dataset.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP and hitting the barrier is attributed to communication/coordination breakdown rather than mechanical failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the aircraft from passing the TRP or hitting the barrier, or if mechanical failure was the cause instead.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) shows communication among crew and a trainee driver stopping pushback and handing over to the instructor, who then corrected the aircraft's path but the aircraft still passed the Tug release point and hit a barrier, indicating observable coordination breakdown supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the continued movement beyond TRP was due to communication breakdown or other factors like mechanical issues.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim data, such as timing and interaction patterns.

assumptions: The described interactions and failure to stop at TRP reflect communication/coordination breakdown rather than other causes.
The key features in the hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim data include timing and interaction patterns similar to those described.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the continued movement beyond TRP was due to environmental or marking deficiencies rather than crew communication issues.
If mechanical or procedural factors unrelated to communication were primary causes.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) shows detailed communication and coordination interactions among crew during pushback, including role changes and continued communication, but also a failure to stop at the TRP, consistent with coordination breakdown key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the failure to stop at TRP was due to communication breakdown or environmental/marking deficiencies

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative explanations do not sufficiently account for the observed coordination issues in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim dataset.

assumptions: The absence of mechanical fault evidence implies mechanical failure is less likely.
Communication and coordination efforts described are representative of the overall crew interaction.
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or hardware failures causing the coordination issues, or if communication was proven ineffective or absent, this would challenge the claim.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the historical pair engine preliminary phase on 12-25.

assumptions: Ground markings (TRP) are assumed to be adequate and visible as no contrary evidence is presented.
Communication between crew and tug operators was effective as no communication breakdown is reported.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the ground markings were inadequate or not visible, this would favor environmental or marking deficiency instead of procedural deviation.
If communication breakdown evidence indicated miscoordination causing the deviation, it would challenge the procedural deviation claim.
If mechanical control failure evidence showed equipment malfunction causing the incident, it would undermine the procedural deviation conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution by showing the aircraft moved beyond the designated release point and hit a barrier, supporting the claim of procedural deviation rather than environmental or marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence about the adequacy or visibility of ground markings or communication clarity is provided, leaving some ambiguity.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim scope, reflecting deviations from standard pushback protocols.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence.
The procedural actions described are representative of the actual pushback event.
defeaters: If evidence of equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating control malfunction were found, this would favor R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE.
If communication breakdown or environmental deficiencies were shown to cause the deviation, this would change the assessment.

node.statement: There is no evidence contradicting the mechanical/control failure as the cause in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim scenario.

defeaters: Evidence of equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating no mechanical malfunction
Communication failures without hardware faults
Physical marking/location evidence inconsistent with control failure

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) shows procedural actions and communications without indication of mechanical/control failure, supporting no contradiction to mechanical/control failure cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity
